attributes.action: unilaterally state that he will seek to give evidence to the Iraq Inquiry before the forthcoming General Election, even though the Inquiry has only requested him to do so afterwards.
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
Other Cabinet Ministers during the Iraq War, who no longer hold the same office, are to give evidence to the Inquiry before the Election. The Prime Minister must be concerned at the delay in his giving evidence to the Iraq Inquiry and the impression given of asymmetric treatment. He must also be concerned at the sclerotic effect that delay has on the UK’s foreign and defence policy.

He was Chancellor of the Exchequer at the time of the Iraq War. The Blair government’s progress was always dictated as much by the Chancellor’s desire to fund certain policies as by the then Prime Minister’s enthusiasm for that policy. This country would not have gone to War had the Treasury – in the person of the then Chancellor, Gordon Brown – not been prepared to pay for it.

The Prime Minister should be concerned that the Inquiry intends him to give evidence only after the forthcoming General Election. He must urge them to allow him to give evidence as soon as possible.

rejection.details: This is an independent inquiry and it is for the inquiry to determine who it calls to give evidence and when they are asked to appear.
reasons: Outside the remit of the Prime Minister and Government
